docs.lead_paragraph: A proposal to provide essential drugs free to hospital patients would fill a gap in health care at India’s state-owned hospitals, many of which require patients to buy their own drugs.

headline.seo: India May Provide Free Drugs at State-Run Hospitals
headline.main: India Weighs Providing Free Drugs at State-Run Hospitals
headline.print_headline: India Weighs Providing Free Drugs at State-Run Hospitals

docs.abstract: India is completing proposal to provide hundreds of essential drugs free to patients in government-run hospitals and clinics at a cost of nearly $5 billion over five years; proposal would fill a gap in health care at the hospitals, many of which require patients to buy their own drugs.
docs.snippet: A proposal to provide essential drugs free to hospital patients would fill a gap in health care at India’s state-owned hospitals, many of which require patients to buy their own drugs.

byline.contributor: Katie Thomas contributed reporting from New York.

docs.lead_paragraph: Data from the Institute for Supply Management showed signs of a weakening economy, but service companies are still hiring, as are factories.

headline.seo: Service Sector Grows at Slowest Pace in Two Years
headline.main: Service Sector Increases at Slowest Pace in 2 Years
headline.print_headline: Service Sector Increases At Slowest Pace in 2 Years

docs.abstract: Institute for Supply Management reports its index of nonmanufacturing activity fell to 52.1 in June, from a May reading of 53.7; reading above 50 indicates expansion, and sector has grown for 30 straight months; Labor Department reports weekly unemployment benefit applications fell by 14,000 to a seasonally adjusted 374,000.
docs.snippet: Data from the Institute for Supply Management showed signs of a weakening economy, but service companies are still hiring, as are factories.

docs.lead_paragraph: Austin, Tex. WORK and opportunity, poverty and dependency, material security and insecurity: for generations of reformers, the constitutional importance of these subjects was self-evident. Laissez-faire government, unchecked corporate power and the deprivations and inequalities they bred weren't just bad public policy -- they were constitutional infirmities. But liberals have largely forgotten how to think, talk and fight along these lines.
docs.abstract: Op-Ed article by law and history professor William E Forbath contends that in the wake of the Supreme Court's ruling on the health care reform law, which provides a new doctrine and dictums for conservatives' attack on the welfare and regulatory state, liberals must provide a constitutional counternarrative supporting the powers of government. Drawing (M)

headline.main: Could States Save by Expanding Medicaid?

docs.abstract: Opting in to the Medicaid provisions under the Affordable Care Act could bring economies to the states in covering care for the indigent, by some calculations.
